Name: TC contaminates environment with amplicon
Sequence of Events:
1. TC seal fails on positive test run
  2. TC amplicons escape to environment

Name: SCC contaminates environment with sample
Sequence of Events:
1. SCC collects sample from an infectious patient
  2. SCC touches objects in environment before transfer into STC or handle touches objects in environment after separation from head in STC

Name: SCC is reused
Sequence of Events:
1. SCC collects sample from an infectious patient
  2. SCC collects sample from a different patient

Name: STC contaminates environment with sample
Sequence of Events:
1. SCC collects sample from an infectious patient
  2. SCC transfers sample into STC
  3. STC spills sample onto workspace or person

Name: STC is reused
Sequence of Events: 1. STC with remnants of sample from an infectious patient is re-opened

Name: SPM contaminates environment with sample
Sequence of Events:
1. a. SPM containment fails during operation or b. STC containment fails inside SPM during operation
  2. SPM shakes infectious sample into the environment

Name: SPM does not inactivate sample
Sequence of Events:
1. a. SPM is mis-calibrated or b. SPM software fails or c. SPM electronics fail
  2. SPM appears to heat and shake but fails to inactivate sample in STC
  3. STC allows transfer of infectious sample to person

Name: SCC is contaminated with manufacturing chemicals
Sequence of Events:
1. SCC is contaminated with chemicals during manufacture
  2. SCC is used to collect sample from person and transfers chemicals to sampling site on person

Name: TC reagents are inhibited by manufacturing chemicals
Sequence of Events:
1. TC is contaminated with chemicals during manufacture
  2. TC reagents do not work in the presence of the chemical or its residue

Name: PM does not amplify
Sequence of Events:
1. a. PM amplification heaters are mis-calibrated or b. PM software fails or c. PM electronics fail
  2. PM appears to heat during amplification but fails to amplify sample in TC

Name: PM does not open valve
Sequence of Events:
1. a. PM valve heater is mis-calibrated or b. PM software fails or c. PM electronics fail
  2. PM appears to heat during valving but fails to allow flow to detection in TC

Name: SCC is contaminated by environment
Sequence of Events:
1. SCC collects MTb from the environment
  2. SCC is used to collect a negative sample

Name: SCC is never added to STC
Sequence of Events: 1. SCC is never added to STC

Name: STC is contaminated by environment
Sequence of Events:
1. STC collects MTb from the environment
  2. STC is used to process a negative sample

Name: STC is opened and left exposed to environment
Sequence of Events: 1. STC is left open until liquid reagents evaporate

Name: STC is removed from SPM during operation
Sequence of Events:
1. STC with positive sample is removed early from SPM
  2. STC transfers insufficiently lysed sample to TC
  3. TC fails to amplify insufficiently lysed sample

Name: STC sample transfer into TC introduces air bubbles
Sequence of Events:
1. STC sample transfer introduces air bubbles into TC
  2. TC fails fluidically because of bubbles

Name: STC sample transfer into TC is delayed
Sequence of Events:
1. STC sample transfer of a positive sample into TC is delayed
  2. STC sample degrades
  3. TC fails to amplify degraded positive sample

Name: STC sample transfer into TC leaks
Sequence of Events:
1. STC sample transfer into TC leaks
  2. TC fails fluidically because of insufficient fluid volume

Name: TC amplification reagents fail during storage
Sequence of Events:
1. TC amplification reagents fail during storage
  2. TC fails to amplify positive sample

Name: TC detection reagents fail during storage
Sequence of Events:
1. TC detection reagents fail during storage
  2. TC fails to detect positive amplicons

Name: TC is contaminated by environment
Sequence of Events:
1. TC collects MTb from the environment
  2. TC is used to test a negative sample

Name: TC is exposed to amplicon during manufacturing
Sequence of Events:
1. TC collects amplicon during manufacture
  2. TC is used to test a negative sample

Name: TC is loaded into PM in wrong orientation
Sequence of Events:
1. TC is loaded into PM in wrong orientation
  2. TC amplification and valve zones are not heated by the PM
  3. TC fails to return a result

Name: TC is opened and left exposed to environment
Sequence of Events:
1. TC is opened and left to sit
  2. TC reagents are partially rehydrated and degrade under environmental conditions
  3. TC is used to test a positive sample

Name: TC is removed from PM during operation
Sequence of Events:
1. TC is removed from PM during operation
  2. TC valve is not heated by PM and does not open

Name: TC is reused
Sequence of Events:
1. TC run on positive sample is re-opened
  2. TC amplicons escape to environment

Name: TC test and control lines show non-specific binding
Sequence of Events:
1. TC is run on a negative sample
  2. TC test and control lines show non-specific binding

Name: TC valve never opens
Sequence of Events: 1. TC valve never opens

Name: TC valve opens early
Sequence of Events:
1. TC is run on a positive sample
  2. TC valve opens too early for target amplification but late enough for IPC amplification

Name: PM batteries overcharge
Sequence of Events: 1. PM batteries overcharge, heat up, and catch fire

Name: PM batteries over-discharge
Sequence of Events:
1. PM batteries over-discharge
  2. PM can no longer hold a charge

Name: PM electrical components fail
Sequence of Events: 1. PM electrical component is of insufficient quality and fails

Name: PM experiences electrostatic discharge
Sequence of Events:
1. PM is touched by person carrying electrostatic charge
  2. PM electronics are damaged by resulting discharge

Name: PM experiences electrical interference
Sequence of Events: 1. PM experiences hardware failure due to voltage and electrical noise caused by nearby EM waves

Name: PM is dropped and breakage exposes electrical circuits
Sequence of Events: 1. PM is dropped and breakage exposes electrical circuits

Name: PM is plugged in to faulty power supply
Sequence of Events:
1. PM is plugged in to faulty power supply
  2. PM electronics overdraw current and catch fire

Name: PM is unplugged during operation on insufficient battery charge
Sequence of Events:
1. PM is unplugged during operation on insufficient battery charge
  2. PM dies during TC operation
  3. TC is invalid

Name: PM placed near magnetic field
Sequence of Events:
1. PM is placed near magnetic field that triggers lid sensor while lid is open
  2. PM amplification and valve heaters turn on while exposed

Name: PM wires are exposed
Sequence of Events:
1. PM internal wiring or power cord insulation breaks down
  2. PM exposed wiring energizes ungrounded enclosure
  3. PM enclosure is touched

Name: STC leaks fluid into SPM
Sequence of Events:
1. STC leaks while in SPM
  2. SPM electronics are shorted by leaking fluid and catch fire

Name: SPM batteries overcharge
Sequence of Events: 1. SPM batteries overcharge, heat up, and catch fire

Name: SPM batteries over-discharge
Sequence of Events:
1. SPM batteries over-discharge
  2. SPM can no longer hold a charge

Name: SPM electrical components fail
Sequence of Events: 1. SPM electrical component is of insufficient quality and fails

Name: SPM experiences electrostatic discharge
Sequence of Events:
1. SPM is touched by person carrying electrostatic charge
  2. SPM electronics are damaged by resulting discharge

Name: SPM experiences electrical interference
Sequence of Events: 1. SPM experiences hardware failure due to voltage and electrical noise caused by nearby EM waves

Name: SPM is dropped and breakage exposes electrical circuits
Sequence of Events: 1. SPM is dropped and breakage exposes electrical circuits

Name: SPM is plugged in to faulty power supply
Sequence of Events:
1. SPM is plugged in to faulty power supply
  2. SPM electronics overdraw current and catch fire

Name: SPM is unplugged during operation on insufficient battery charge
Sequence of Events:
1. SPM is unplugged during operation on insufficient battery charge
  2. SPM dies during STC operation
  3. STC contains a positive sample that is insufficiently lysed

Name: SPM placed near magnetic field
Sequence of Events:
1. SPM is placed near magnetic field that triggers lid sensor while lid is open
  2. SPM shakes while exposed

Name: SPM wires are exposed
Sequence of Events:
1. SPM internal wiring or power cord insulation breaks down
  2. SPM exposed wiring energizes ungrounded enclosure
  3. SPM enclosure is touched

Name: PM is dropped on person
Sequence of Events: 1. PM is dropped on person

Name: PM magnetic closure pinches
Sequence of Events: 1. PM lid is closed on fingers and magnetic closure causes pinch

Name: SPM connector fails during shaking
Sequence of Events:
1. SPM connecter fails mechanically
  2. SPM is unusable

Name: SPM is dropped on person
Sequence of Events: 1. SPM is dropped on person

Name: SPM loses control of shaker
Sequence of Events:
1. SPM shaker control fails
  2. SPM shakes even when lid is open

Name: SPM observation window breaks
Sequence of Events: 1. SPM observation window breaks

Name: SPM magnetic closure pinches
Sequence of Events: 1. SPM lid is closed on fingers and magnetic closure causes pinch

Name: SPM shakes while open
Sequence of Events: 1. SPM fails to stop shaking when lid is opened

Name: SPM vibrates off of surface during shaking
Sequence of Events: 1. SPM vibrates off surface during shaking and falls on a person

Name: System damaged by shipping
Sequence of Events: 1. System is inadequately packed and is unusable at customer site

Name: TC is dropped
Sequence of Events:
1. TC is dropped after sample introduction from STC
  2. TC sample is displaced on impact and causes air blockage and fluidic failure

Name: PM lid fails under thermal stress
Sequence of Events:
1. PM is operated repeatedly
  2. PM lid fails because of thermal stress on material above heater
  3. PM heater is exposed through lid

Name: PM loses control of heater
Sequence of Events:
1. PM heater control fails
  2. PM heats uncontrollably until it catches fire

Name: PM valve heater is exposed to touch at max temp
Sequence of Events: 1. PM lid is opened during operation

Name: STC melts during heating in SPM
Sequence of Events:
1. STC is operated in SPM
  2. STC melts onto electronics, and they catch fire

Name: SPM loses control of heater
Sequence of Events:
1. SPM heater control fails
  2. SPM heats uncontrollably until it catches fire
